topics.body:
"@HJSDGCE":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53617a8263687270ad710100#post_53617a8263687270ad710100
Although massively sarcastic that kind of is what it could do costs wise.  A lot of costs when it comes to building large buildings is constructing everything, transporting it onto site, laying down the concrete and a lot of stuff.  While it won't make hundreds of millions dollar houses something you can buy it would massively reduce the sticker price.



Oh hey another win for glbt rights in the usa:  Transgender rights in schools are now protected under title 9.



Also a bit of politics:
2014 midterm elections in the usa are not as big of a deal as how much it's getting played out to be.  Short version is we're in for the same shit the next two years in congress.  Only 6 senate seats are contested; republicans aren't going to gain control of senate cause the probability of them gaining all six contested seats is too low.  It would be like having to hit six home runs in winnie the pooh's homerun derby against christopher robin in a row.  There I just saved you months worth of hearing about this on the news.

Most likely outcome of the 2014 elections summarized in one sentence:
Between 53 to 51 for democrats and 47 to 49 for republicans.

topics.body:
so i dont know what the fuck happened, but after running bleach bit my local disc are just FILLED, i mean my disc d was in 400 now its in 200 gb.

all i know is i got these really big tmp and random letter blank files, which im deleting.
topics.author: 5154c5237f123bcd580002fc

topics.body:
"@twistedmetalero":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53619bda63687248b90f0000#post_53619bda63687248b90f0000
That's cause bleachbit has to fill those areas then delete them to overwrite them.

If you interrupted it then you're going to have to rerun it again and do NOT interrupt it.  That's why I said to not interrupt it, cause in order to overwrite unused space and delete deleted files that just have their registry. . . Short easy version is you don't want to interrupt bleachbit otherwise you'll have this problem, rerun it, don't interrupt it and fixed.  It has to 100% complete uninterrupted so it doesn't cause this problem.

Tl:dr; This problem is cause it was interrupted, just rerun it, wait until it says "Done" then fixed.

topics.body:
"@HJSDGCE":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53617a8263687270ad710100#post_53617a8263687270ad710100
While that may sound good, think of the consequences of that. If everyone can have a cheap house that means for more people will have houses which means far more crowding. Not to mention people who already can have a house can now have a much bigger one. Land will be used up fast. In my area a place that used to be untouched wilderness is now a suburb full of yuppies. A place where I liked to go to take walks and fish and such is now someones backyard poisoned with fertilizer and pesticides which run of in the rain into what little of the wilderness is left.

Also think of what that will do to apartment owners. Landlords will lose tenets who can now afford a house and thus may have to raise prices for the people that choose to stay. Property prices will go up quickly as more land becomes scarce also.
topics.author: 5010fa077f123b1e4f00104e

topics.body:
"@someguy111":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53619f916368722662210000#post_53619f916368722662210000
Okay, I have to correct something here; if house prices are slashed by a third then while yes people want bigger houses, but apartments and skyscrapers as well become much cheaper as well.

The biggest effect this would have on the economy is people would have more disposable income.  Say your current house/apartment costs $1000.00/month and the next apartment you move into only costs $666.66/month then that $233.33 extra a month in your pocket is going into the economy.

Also people are moving more and more into cities, not into the country.


The biggest problem this would cause is millions of homes would go without owners until they finally fall down due to being abandoned for so long. . Oh wait, cause of the housing crash we already have that problem.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5361a2496368726ace3e0000#post_5361a2496368726ace3e0000
True, but it will also increase mortgage rates because the lower prices mean the same percent will yield less interest for the banks. People looking to buy an existing house will now have to pay a higher rate to make up for the loss of interest. Also property taxes will go up as the overall value of a property includes what the house is worth. Let's say the a property is worth 150k with the property it self worth 10k and the other 140 for the house. if the property tax is 4mils that's 600 dollars per year. Now if the price dropped on the house from 140 to say 50, the total cost would be 60. At 4mils that would be 240 dollars a year. The city would have to raise the property tax to get back the money it would lose. That means that everyone in the area would have to pay more. Not to mention property prices will increase as well as more land used up.
topics.author: 5010fa077f123b1e4f00104e

topics.body:
"@someguy111":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5361a4b363687256dcb80100#post_5361a4b363687256dcb80100
Okay, let me stop you here.  There's 25 houses for every homeless person in the usa; we have so many unused houses that detroit is outright giving people houses for near free rather than having to pay the demolition costs.  We already have this problem.

All these new houses would do is cause the exact same problem at the exact same rate _just_ in a different manner.

It's like saying puffing carcinogenic aerosol spray cans would give you "super" lung cancer vs "regular" lung cancer from cigarettes.  Either way you're going to have lung cancer and there is no such thing as "super" cancer.
